Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Wireless Health Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives are to advance the state of the art in methods of wireless health. Projects span the range of end-to-end systems including robust inference using body networks of sensors, real-time and energy efficient analysis of sensor data using smartphones, development of effective interfaces and other feedback mechanisms, and construction of readily searchable large-scale databases of time series data. Collectively, the projects enable quantitative determination of patient state and compliance with therapy, and thus facilitate large-scale clinical studies that evaluate the effectiveness of particular therapies. Projects related to inference of human motion and provision of appropriate feedback also have application to sports training and the learning of other physical skills.

The broader impacts include training of undergraduate researchers by graduate mentors and their inspiration to pursue graduate studies. The summer research is designed to develop materials that refresh capstone design courses and produce hands-on activities that are added to lecture courses. The research of the graduate mentors, the summer research, and the capstone design activities are all closely related in a cycle that advances research and training in each phase.

Additional information is provided at the project web site (http://www.wirelesshealth.ucla.edu/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The infusion of information technology into the practice of medicine can have wide ranging societal benefits. The focus of this project was to inspire and train the next generation of engineers and computer scientists who can work at the intersection of these disciplines with medicine. As an example, some of research projects included highly accurate tracking of the motions of human limbs using low cost devices, so that doctors can have accurate records of whether/how patients are performing exercises necessary for their recovery, and adjust treatment. This can lower costs of therapy, and tune it to the needs of individuals. It represents a significant advance over the current state of the art, in which patient self-reports are both subjective and usually optimistic.

In our program, some of the projects performed by undergraduates in the summer became the basis of senior design courses or even graduate project courses. The graduate students who mentored the students in summer were also teaching assistants for these classes, and extended the work themselves as part of their doctoral theses and in publications in technical conferences. Thus the research refreshed courses that in a typical year reached an additional 50-75 students, enabling a much broader set of students to become familiar with wireless health in challenging and up to date hands-on activities. 

The site offered each year a set of workshops to the participants to help prepare them to continue to pursue their technical abilities, either for graduate school or the workforce. These activities were opened up to include students from community colleges pursuing summer research throughout engineering in a separate program. The site also recruited a signficant number of community college students itself, as part of its effort to build a diverse workforce.
